Title: Everybody's Coming to My House
Comment: Byrne was 66 when this came out. Had the good fortune to see the American Utopia tour which was incredible and showed that at 66 Byrne was still spry as fuck

Title: Little Boxes
Comment:
Born in 1900, Malvina Reynolds was 66 when this was released. 

She seems to have had figured out what mattered to her and what didn’t by then. The unpolished sound, the expression on her face, and the straightforward title of the album “Sings the Truth” all feel refreshing to me. 

I recommend checking her other (less catchy) stuff out. She was always on the right side of history.

Title: Damn Your Eyes
Comment:
Becoming a music nerd takes a lot of growth. But you have to have an open mind, and have the right people around you. And so I go back to the early 90s, the most formative years for me, musically. 

The station I'm listening to plays literally everything. Tons of punk and ska. A fair share of metal. Lots of reggae. Some grunge, and classic rock sprinkled in. Surprisingly dope hip hop, and every few hours, a curve ball. I wasn't looking for that pitch, but I needed to experience it. 

I hadn't heard her classics yet. I didn't know her history. But I had never heard a voice like that, and it knocked me over. I didn't know she had stacks of undeniable bangers, but was often ignored by the powers that be. But I could hear it in her voice.

I didn't realize this was her at the age of 50, at a crossroads. She recorded this in 1988. A new age was right around the corner. I didn't know she was gone for years, waiting for the industry to throw her a bone again. But I heard it all in her voice.

Title: Melodie Is A Wound
Comment: Lætitia Sadier, 57

Title: Lucy's World
Comment: Guided by voices didn't break into the mainstream until Robert Pollard was in his mid forties. Now he's 68, still releasing an album a year, and just put this song out last month. Never give up, old-timers.

Title: Where You Find Me
Comment:
The Notwist was formed in 1989. 

Vocalist Markus Acher was 53 when this came out in 2021.

Also, if you're not familiar with The Notwist in general, go listen to Neon Golden too. An absolute classic album.

Title: Padam Padam
Comment: Kylie was 55 when she released Padam Padam in 2023 and it immediately became the sexiest song of the summer. She is a pop legend and continues to stand the test of time with each new release. An unbelievable performer live as well, Kylie we salute you

Title: Cold at Night
Album: Cold at Night / Rocks in My Pockets
Comment: John Danielle is 58 years old. I think old age is making his voice slightly more palatable, but mostly I’m impressed that his lyrical prowess has remained so steady.

Title: Queasy
Comment:
Thalia Zedek sang and played guitar in bands like Uzi, Live Skull, and Come through the 80s and 90s, then started doing her own stuff in the 2000s - mostly a bit mellower (although still very intense). But here she is at 60* showing she's still very much got it. 

* Or maybe 59, she was born in 1961 but I can't find out what date.

Title: Oh My Heart
Comment: Stipe was 51 when this was released! Love this song!!

Title: Hold
Album: Let All That We Imagine Be The Light
Comment: Shirley Ann Manson, born Aug. 26, 1966, age 58 when this came out. There’s another track on the album where she actually sings about being “too old” and how women in rock in particular are seen as having an expiration date, but I thought that might be too on the nose. Anyway, she rules and I’m glad the band is still intact and making music.

Title: Pressure to Cum
Comment:
At :37, soft fade to a montage of photos of the horses we just saw, Then a voice over:

"It's hard being a horse", says Carl, a former stud, "no pun intended. Heh. We're so happy to have built this community of free horses. When I was in captivity I was expected to blow loads all day. That's too much pressure. Now the only loads I have to worry about is loads of fun!"

"And how!", says Rose. "It's so freeing being out in the middle of nowhere. Nobody riding us or trying to feed us food they think we want. We'd rather explore and look for our own stuff. Plus it gave me the confidence to open up a book store with my partner, Carolina, who happens to be an otter."

"Sometimes we eat too many of those funky berries and dance so hard, we pass out.", says Rene. "But we're always there to help each other out, and pick each other up. We're just trying to live a simple life out here. We don't want to bother anybody and we don't want anybody bothering us. P.S. Slayer rules!"

fade out

FIN

Title: Nettie Moore
Comment:
The year is 1913. Modern society is rapidly advancing on the fictional town of Tumbledown, Arizona.

Local rancher Dan The Horse Man is struggling to pay the mortgage on his family’s famed riding hall, Horsey Hostel, eventually forcing into auction where it is purchased by the notorious tycoon Ace Moneybags Jenkins. Dan is devastated and pleads with Jenkins to allow him to keep his prized mare and companion Nettie. This request is ultimately refused setting the stage for the 157th greatest revenge story ever told.

I’ll let you fill in the blanks as I’m running out of space, but there are guns, dynamite, and classic one liners like ‘I AM DAN. THE HORSE MAN. I BELIEVE YOU HAVE MY HORSE.’

In the film’s climax, Dan concocts a brilliant plan to convince all of the horses at the ranch to stampede and trample Ace, but ultimately abandons the idea in favor of just shooting him and burning down the ranch after letting the horses free.

This is obv the closing scene and credits song.

Title: New Slang
Comment:
I picture this as like a kinda weird dream. I saw a horse during the day and was also a little sad, so then my brain made this.
The lyrics and the scene made no literal sense, but somehow the tone works for dream.
Then wake up and think why the hell did i just dream that.

Title: Picture of a Tree That Doesn't Look Okay
Artist(s): The World Is A Beautiful Place & I Am No Longer Afraid To Die
Comment:
The first 90 seconds or so fit the video nicely imo, so we can assume this pace and mood is kept to pretty closely for about that long. Then they all start speeding up a little at a time, you know, canter to trot to gallop type shit. By about 2:15 all these motherfuckers are just running full tilt and it's sick as fuck. Then at the very very end when it slows again for just a second they stop dramatically and kick up a ton of dust clouds.

No narrative and all visual emotion for this one tbh. It's not how I usually operate,  let's see how it goes.

Title: Cranes in the Sky
Comment: It's not exactly timed, but starting the song and the video at the same time, there's a peaceful intro before the horses begin moving just as Solange starts singing about getting away from heartbreak.

Title: Diamonds And Rust
Comment: The clip and the song start at the same time. The clip continues by the horses continuing to move out of frame. Until a lone cowboy enters the left of the frame on his own horse. He is attempting to corrall the wild mustangs towards his ranch. The song continues playing as the camera pans between horses running in slow motion, close-ups of the cowboys concentrated face as he sweats beneath the brim of his stetson, with dust rising all around them from the flurry of hooves. It is the opening credit sequence to an epic modern western that will inevitably be perfectly gay

Title: Unexpected Token
Comment:
This scene is early in the movie. It's relatively abstract and doesn't reveal any big plot points, but it's big for setting and mood. So I think an instrumental song with a defined beat that follows the horses' motion and establishes a sort of offbeat, artsy mood is the perfect soundtrack.

0:00: song starts out with fewer instruments to match fewer horses
0:06: another instrumental layer as that white and brown horse enters from the left
0:13: song builds again as the dark brown horses join in
0:21: the beat is getting stronger and the horses are starting to trot
0:30: song starts to drop back a bit as horses exit the scene, but still plenty of jaunty trotting bass 
0:37: bye, horses! The next scene would catch up with them down the road, some trotting more happily than others

Title: The Medic
Comment:
Picture a man sitting alone on a porch at sunrise, coffee in hand, looking out over a quiet stretch of land. He sees these horses from his porch every morning. They move steady and unfazed, with no sense of past or future. He wishes he had that.

You, the audience, hear this song start right at 0:00 as he watches.

He thinks of the things she used to say to him. “You always smell like cigarettes…” She said it with disdain, but he almost misses it now.

He remembers the last thing he ever said to her. “But you’re the best that I can do.” The line rolls through his mind on this quiet, reflective morning.

Nothing dramatic happens. Nothing big shifts. It is just a man replaying the same thoughts that return every time he watches that herd move past the water.

Title: Down Below Him
Comment:
[the start of the clip matches the start of the song]

In the first 37 seconds of the song we've seen the horses walk slowly towards the edge of shot. Following this, the last horse in the pack senses something, slows, turns and trots across the shallow water.

The horse reaches the other side of the water and starts nuzzling at an unconscious figure lying half on the ground and half in the water. The figure comes to. She's a woman in her sixties, wearing a wedding dress that dates from 19th century. But as she gets up she seems to have no idea why she'd be wearing it. 

The horse kneels as if inviting the woman to get on. She does, and the horse rises and starts walking. The woman spurs the horse into a canter, but seems confused at so how she did so and how she is able to stay balanced.

She feels something in the collar of her dress, and reaches out a scrap of folded-up yellowing paper. She opens it. There's just one line of handwritten inked text, reading: "This is the fifth time".

Title: Thunderhorse
Comment:
The horses graze by the water. Then they start running…. Fleeing?? Then, a large horse clad in armor with a shadowy figure straddled on top appear. Each gallop sounds like a sickening thunderclap. The horses run every which way. But the Thunder Horse isn’t after them. The Thunder Horse is only in need of bloodthirsty revenge. 

Against Seabiscuit. It’s arch neigh-mesis!

Title: Living Is Easy
Comment:
54k monthly listeners

This band has been a recent favorite. I try to share them any time I get a chance.

This song feels like the perfect combo of black metal and catchy

It’s something Deafheaven has tried to do but it always sounded a little too polished for black metal

This feels like the right amount of grit, authenticity and groove.

Title: Sledgehammer
Comment: def thought these guys had more than a million listeners but then i remembered guitar hero is like... a million years old at this point. they're a pretty varied band - not quite metal - not quite anything else - but the breakdown toward the end of this one is decidedly metal as fuck

Title: Cheeky Bastard
Comment: Enjoy some folk metal from this Irish band with 181k monthly listeners

Title: DEAD TO ME!
Comment:
witch fever are amy, alex, alisha and annabelle, and they have around 92k monthly listeners

vocalist amy was raised within a christian sect and this song excoriates the church elders that let her down and are now dead to her

Title: Dissipate
Comment: 1m listeners. Good track, love the artwork

Title: Orchard
Comment: 87.2K listeners.I I enjoy the drone of this particular song but I love her voice most of all. It makes me think if Grace Slick were in a metal band. I read a tiny write-up of this band on Revolver which is how o found out about them. This song was the first I heard of them and I was sold.

Title: Time Stands Still (At the Iron Hill) - Remastered 2007
Comment:
614k

My metal knowledge is not deep, but I have a special connection to this song because back in sixth grade or so it was pretty much the first time I ever heard metal that wasn't by someone *obnoxiously* famous, you know? Plus it was around the same time I was first reading the Silmarillion, so the whole album was just really cool to hear.

Also, if you're considering docking points because it's nerd shit: yes it is, but it's metal so they get to get away with it

Title: For Horror Eats The Light
Comment: 4886 listeners. This song is hypnotizing. So satisfyingly bleak and heavy (as one would expect for an album about “isolation, depression, and misanthropy”), while also beautifully textured and atmospheric. Sort of like doom metal meets shoegaze, which is why they call it … doomgaze! I learned a new metal subgenre name today!

Title: Evil
Comment: I honestly don't listen to that much metal, and even less obscure metal bands, but 160k listeners seems to fit the assignment and I like these guys so have at it.

Title: This Is It
Comment:
I'm not sure how many of you are metalheads, so I tried not to post anything too abrasive. Once upon a time, even I didn't understand Cookie Monster vocals. It took time for me to enjoy, as Brian Posehn once called it, "the sound of demons fucking."

So what I give to you instead is a bit of comedy metal, for lack of a better term. Or heavy meta, if you will. (Please say you won't)

Nekrogoblikon are kind of confusing. The lead singer was a goblin in khakis. But now they have two singers, and I think only one of them is still a goblin. And in his free time, that goblin has a comedy podcast.

Whether or not this song is a joke, it still slaps, and is catchy as all get out. And it won't give you nightmares.

Title: Vicious Riffs
Comment: Turns out the verbs aren’t really that nervous and the riffs aren’t that vicious either. Just nice songs from an artist with a shockingly low number of listeners! The album cover art instantly drew me in, too.

Title: Holy Roller
Artist(s): Thao, Thao & The Get Down Stay Down
Comment: In all fairness, I learned the name and the(deserved) good reputation about the same time, but Thao & The Get Down Stay Down is one of the all-time great band names. And Thao Nguyen 100% backs it up, she is an honest to God genius as far as I'm concerned.

Title: Yellow Moon
Comment: When I first heard of this band, I was definitely curious. Then I saw the album cover. I was like, perfect! They got a great sound. I’m not into the vocals as much but I like their music. Here’s a nice moody instrumental. Long live 70s horror!

Title: I Want To Believe
Comment: Didn't know what to expect but an Australian punk band singing about cryptids wasn't it and I love it

Title: Holy Smoke
Comment:
Would've also been a good fit for the "drummer is the singer" round if I'd known about them back then - they're a sister & brother duo with her singing & playing drums, and him playing other instruments, mostly bass.  

"SLAP RASH" promises a lot as a band name, but they definitely delivered what I was hoping for.

Title: You Wouldn't Understand
Comment:
If I remember correctly, Spin did a profile on them, and I was instantly in. I loved the name of the group. The album title was also an attention grabber, and the cover looked great.

To top it all off, the group members looked cool as fuck. Nobody looked cooler in the early to mid 90s than black dudes dressed like skaters. I would argue there still aren't many better looks.

Unfortunately, they kind of disappeared after this album, but for a minute there, it looked like The Pharcyde, and Souls of Mischief, etc., had some real competition, and I was definitely looking forward to their next move.

Title: Nothing Matters
Comment: This is the most recent band that I listened to because I was intrigued by their name! Used to adopt this method all the time when reading music magazines and decising who to look out for on the music channel on TV lol

Title: Colombian Necktie
Comment: I didn't even know it was an albini project at first. Just the name felt so imposing and looming I had to know what it was all about. Still one of my favorite bands

Title: nancy's hell
Comment:
Couldn't not check out a band named "ira glass."

I was pleasantly surprised to learn they are experimental noise
and not sad, sappy emo or indie.

I think both Ira and Philip Glass would be proud.
